Title: American Shaolin: King of Kickboxers II
Author: Keith Strandburg

I saw a Shaolin monk once. I was only 5 years old at the time, but I remember it like it was yesterday. I was coming back from the market with my father. Soldiers stopped us and were taking the food we had just bought.
Just as the soldiers were leaving, a monk stepped out of the crowd and told them very calmly to put the food back.
I never did, though. My family left China and ended up here in New York, a young boy's dream left behind in  China.
Made up. I never trained at the Shaolin Temple. When I realized my dream couldn't come true, I convinced myself that it had anyway. It was a small step to convince other people.

In order to keep our bodies strong, Bodhidharma gave us a series of exercises and breathing techniques. Because the times demanded action, we developed Shaolin style wu shu from these exercises.
The spirit of Bodhidharma remains. Training is like meditation. Be aware of everything, but aware of nothing in particular. Think not thinking.
Non thinking.
Your training begins today, in this most sacred of training halls. The floor bears witness to the efforts of fighting monks from centuries past.
At the Shaolin temple, we forge our bodies in the fire of our wills. We adhere to a vow of non-violence, unless someone else is in danger... Follow my movements...

You are to deliver this scroll to the Arhat living on the  Jade Mountain. This is your quest. The scroll that is in this box is more precious than life. Guard it well.
If you deliver this, you may ask this master, the most advanced monk of the Shaolin tradition, any question you wish, and he must answer it.
This map will lead you to the Jade Mountain. Let nothing deter from safeguarding the sacred scroll. You leave first thing tomorrow morning.
You must return within three day... or don't bother to return at all.
The scroll that is in this box is more precious than life. Guard it well.
